messages: 50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:05): as julian posted to the announce list, no agenda has been circulated, and no notice that today's meeting will be held (http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-wg-announce/2008JulSep/0019.html)
50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:09): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef, is there indeed a telecon today?
50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:13): so, what's the rule of thumb?  if no chair or staff appear, we give up on meeting after how many minutes?  15? 30?
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (19:13): I think the best plan is to have given up the meeting about five minutes ago
50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:14): lol - you are wise, indeed, b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f
50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:14): not much on the agenda tracker - and those that are on it are "in process"
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (19:14): well, the rule is that you give up if you don't see an agenda 24hrs in advance... I got confusing signals about how long Mike Smith's vacation was.
50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:15): well, i know about the 24 rule, but also know how overcommitted you, chris and mike are, and that the tracker forms the agenda (usually)
50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:16): hey, chris - just pondering if there is actually a call today
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:16): proposes getting rid of chairs to avoid this problem
50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:16): ROTFFL
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:16): 50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5: You see a problem with it, or what's so funny?

50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:16): as julian posted to the announce list, no agenda has been circulated, and no notice that today's meeting will be held (http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-wg-announce/2008JulSep/0019.html)
50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:17): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, a problem with what - i thought you were advancing a "modest proposal"
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (19:17): Mike and I apparently had a disconnect.  He was supposed to be back from vacation today and he was going to chair, and I got in a few minutes late.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:17): 50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5: Getting rid of chairs
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (19:18): I got confused about how long mike's vacation was too.
50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:18): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, then we'd have a standing committee
50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:18): so, no call?
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (19:18): or a benevolent dictator.  Oh, wait.
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (19:18): well, I'm on the phone just in case, but no, I don't expect so.
50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:18): thanks
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:22): Someone should just set up a cron job to send the weekly meeting announcements
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (19:36): maybe should have volunteered to step in as team contact...
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:36): We should get rid of team contacts too.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:37): Rely on unanimous consensus for everything.
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (19:37): Ah, so REALLY get nothing done.  Or did you mean to limit the membership/involvement?
50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:37): i move to change the dialog to interprative dance
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:37): Replace each member of the WG with a small shell script
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (19:37): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: There's another kind of consensus?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:38): s/consensus/agreement/
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:38): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: There's animous consensus
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:38): eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee: Exactly. I guess we could leave membership to W3C members only, but then I'd have to leave, so I can't suggest that.
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (19:38): bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2: http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/consensus - consensus is a majority of opinion, not necessarily unanimity.
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (19:39): yeah, a lot of people mix up unanimity and consensus

eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (19:40): so despite kinda liking the interpretive dance idea from 50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5, I'm happy to have a real discussion about how to improve how we work.
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:40): oed.com says "consensus: ... Agreement in opinion; the collective unanimous opinion of a number of persons."
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (19:40): So basically, the invited experts can vote everyone else off the island
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (19:40): ideally, consensus is reached because the majority is convinced of the technical merits of the "right" solution
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:40): so I guess there isn't consensus on what consensus means
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (19:41): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: go stand in a corner :)
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (19:41): I'd call it ironic, but there's no consensus on that either
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:41): Can we have a Big Brother style voting people off the WG?

eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (19:41): Not true - that was definition 2a of consensus from OED, def 1 was "General agreement or concord of different parts or organs of the body in effecting a given purpose; sympathy. Hence transf. of the members or parts of any system of things. "
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (19:42): so it's simply that there are multiple definitions, and (_I_ think) we function under def 1.
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (19:42): we could enforce Good Standing, a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (19:42): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: I see what you did there.  :)
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:42): eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee: Oops, I only read the first sentence, and thought that discussion of bodily organs wasn't relevant
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:43): 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6: But some requirements like attending WG meetings are unpractical with people who can't afford to attend them
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:43): 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6: It that's too well defined. We need voting!
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (19:43): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: sure, but the chairs/group can define what the qualifications for Good Standing are

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:44): 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6: Is it not defined in the process doc. which we are chartered to work under, though? But I guess by ignoring it entirely we're all ready breaching it anyway‚Ä¶
37905b9b4fdb8fa311b30448254d51fe (19:44): W3C Definition of Concensus:

37905b9b4fdb8fa311b30448254d51fe (19:44): "Consensus: A substantial number of individuals in the set support the decision and nobody in the set registers a Formal Objection. Individuals in the set may abstain. Abstention is either an explicit expression of no opinion or silence by an individual in the set. Unanimity is the particular case of consensus where all individuals in the set support the decision (i.e., no individual in the set abstains)."
37905b9b4fdb8fa311b30448254d51fe (19:44): http://www.w3.org/2005/10/Process-20051014/policies#Consensus
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:45): 37905b9b4fdb8fa311b30448254d51fe: I didn't specify what definition I was using, and it can't have been the W3C one, as I said it was unanimous
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:46): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Your use of the word "unanimous" could have just been subsetting the W3C definition
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (19:49): heheh
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:49): burns the W3C Process document
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:49): does that clarify what def I was using?
bb76dfcc4f591df0120c3ef31743d8e2 (19:50): w3c consensus... on fire?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:50): I dunno.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:50): I can't remember what consensus meant.
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (19:50): is biting his tongue to not be snarky at this point - so is going off to get coffee. brb.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:50): eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee: Did you ever get the coffee machine I showed you? :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:51): (like, the _old_ <http://omgwtf.superlime.com/casemod/caffeine_machine_1.jpg>)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (19:55): eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee, can you explain why this registry fix doesn't work with XP SP3 and IE8 beta? http://support.microsoft.com/kb/945402/
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (19:57): eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee: I have a problem with StickyKeys on Windows 95... I can't turn it off via the dialog... can you explain how to fix that?

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (19:57): 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6, wtf? I only asked eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee cause he *works* with IE8, so I thought he might either know why it's broken, or be interested to know that it's a bug
50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (19:58): um, i think it is called "irony"
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (19:58): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: http://www.google.com/search?q=define%3A+joke&ie=utf-8&oe=utf-8&aq=t&rls=org.mozilla:en-US:official&client=firefox-a
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (19:59): 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6, due to the lack of relevance, it seemed that you were trying to make a point about this not being a help desck
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:59): 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6: I'm not sure that problem can be solved by software - you might want to try wiping your keyboard instead
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (19:59): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: back into the corner, young man!
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (20:00): This IRC channel needs to be Closed Captioned for the humor impaired
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:00): 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6: Hey! I'm the young man here!
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (20:00): on reflection, that is an unfortunate name for a feature...
f4c7f64710edfe9a764166322853fa46 (20:01): maybe each line should have an alt= attribute
50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5 (20:01): HTML = help the millions learn?

227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (20:01): (for the record, I really did have that problem)

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:04): 50fa2422c663a31e707bdd4f9e4ed4c5: If there's one thing it isn't, it's that.
